metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: Responsive Web Design - Images
Resize the browser window to see how the image scales to fit the page.
content.html: Resize the browser window to see how the image scales to fit the page.

content.text: Using The width Property
If the width property is set to a percentage and the height property is set to "auto", the image will be responsive and scale up and down:
content.html: If the width property is set to a percentage and the height property is set to "auto", the image will be responsive and scale up and down:

content.code_html:
img {
  width: 100%;
  height: auto;
}

content.text: Notice that in the example above, the image can be scaled up to be larger than its original size. A better solution, in many cases, will be to use the max-width property instead.
content.html: Notice that in the example above, the image can be scaled up to be larger than its original size. A better solution, in many cases, will be to use the max-width property instead.

content.text: Using The max-width Property
If the max-width property is set to 100%, the image will scale down if it has to, but never scale up to be larger than its original size:
content.html: If the max-width property is set to 100%, the image will scale down if it has to, but never scale up to be larger than its original size:

content.code_html:
img {
  max-width: 100%;
  height: auto;
}

content.text: Add an Image to The Example Web Page

content.code_html:
img {
  width: 100%;
  height: auto;
}

content.text: Background Images
Background images can also respond to resizing and scaling.
content.html: Background images can also respond to resizing and scaling.

content.text: Here we will show three different methods:
content.html: Here we will show three different methods:

content.text: 1. If the background-size property is set to "contain", the background image will scale, and try to fit the content area. However, the image will keep its aspect ratio (the proportional relationship between the image's width and height):
content.html: 1. If the background-size property is set to "contain", the background image will scale, and try to fit the content area. However, the image will keep its aspect ratio (the proportional relationship between the image's width and height):

content.text: Here is the CSS code:
content.html: Here is the CSS code:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
div {  width: 100%;  height: 400px;  
background-image: url('img_flowers.jpg');  background-repeat: no-repeat;  background-size: contain;  border: 1px solid red;}

width: 100%;  height: 400px;  
background-image: url('img_flowers.jpg');  background-repeat: no-repeat;  background-size: contain;  border: 1px solid red;

content.code:
div {  width: 100%;  height: 400px;
background-image: url('img_flowers.jpg');  background-repeat: no-repeat;  background-size: contain;  border: 1px solid red;}

syntax_highlighting.text:
div {  width: 100%;  height: 400px;  
background-image: url('img_flowers.jpg');  background-repeat: no-repeat;  background-size: contain;  border: 1px solid red;}

width: 100%;  height: 400px;  
background-image: url('img_flowers.jpg');  background-repeat: no-repeat;  background-size: contain;  border: 1px solid red;

content.code_html:
div {
  width: 100%;
  height: 400px;
  background-image: url('img_flowers.jpg');
  background-repeat: no-repeat;
  background-size: contain;
  border: 1px solid red;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
div {  width: 100%;  height: 400px;  
background-image: url('img_flowers.jpg');  background-repeat: no-repeat;  background-size: contain;  border: 1px solid red;}

width: 100%;  height: 400px;  
background-image: url('img_flowers.jpg');  background-repeat: no-repeat;  background-size: contain;  border: 1px solid red;

content.text: 2. If the background-size property is set to "100% 100%", the background image will stretch to cover the entire content area:
content.html: 2. If the background-size property is set to "100% 100%", the background image will stretch to cover the entire content area:

content.text: Here is the CSS code:
content.html: Here is the CSS code:

content.code_html:
div {
  width: 100%;
  height: 400px;
  background-image: url('img_flowers.jpg');
  background-size: 100% 100%;
  border: 1px solid red;
}

content.text: 3. If the background-size property is set to "cover", the background image will scale to cover the entire content area. Notice that the "cover" value keeps the aspect ratio, and some part of the background image may be clipped:
content.html: 3. If the background-size property is set to "cover", the background image will scale to cover the entire content area. Notice that the "cover" value keeps the aspect ratio, and some part of the background image may be clipped:

content.text: Here is the CSS code:
content.html: Here is the CSS code:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
div {  width: 100%;  height: 400px;  
background-image: url('img_flowers.jpg');  background-size: cover;  border: 1px solid red;}

width: 100%;  height: 400px;  
background-image: url('img_flowers.jpg');  background-size: cover;  border: 1px solid red;

content.code:
div {  width: 100%;  height: 400px;
background-image: url('img_flowers.jpg');  background-size: cover;  border: 1px solid red;}

syntax_highlighting.text:
div {  width: 100%;  height: 400px;  
background-image: url('img_flowers.jpg');  background-size: cover;  border: 1px solid red;}

width: 100%;  height: 400px;  
background-image: url('img_flowers.jpg');  background-size: cover;  border: 1px solid red;

content.code_html:
div {
  width: 100%;
  height: 400px;
  background-image: url('img_flowers.jpg');
  background-size: cover;
  border: 1px solid red;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
div {  width: 100%;  height: 400px;  
background-image: url('img_flowers.jpg');  background-size: cover;  border: 1px solid red;}

width: 100%;  height: 400px;  
background-image: url('img_flowers.jpg');  background-size: cover;  border: 1px solid red;

content.text: Different Images for Different Devices

A large image can be perfect on a big computer screen, but useless on a small device. Why load a large image when you have to scale it down anyway? To reduce the load, or for any other reasons, you can use media queries to display different images on different devices.
content.html: A large image can be perfect on a big computer screen, but useless on a small device. Why load a large image when you have to scale it down anyway? To reduce the load, or for any other reasons, you can use media queries to display different images on different devices.

content.text: Here is one large image and one smaller image that will be displayed on different devices:
content.html: Here is one large image and one smaller image that will be displayed on different devices:

content.code_html:
/* For width smaller than 400px: */
body {
  background-image: url('img_smallflower.jpg');
}

/* For width 400px and larger: */
@media only screen and (min-width: 400px) {
  body {
    background-image: url('img_flowers.jpg');
  }
}

content.text: You can use the media query min-device-width , instead of min-width , which checks the device width, instead of the browser width. Then the image will not change when you resize the browser window:
content.html: You can use the media query min-device-width, instead of min-width, which checks the device width, instead of the browser width. Then the image will not change when you resize the browser window:

content.code_html:
/* For devices smaller than 400px: */
body {
  background-image: url('img_smallflower.jpg');
}

/* For devices 400px and larger: */
@media only screen and (min-device-width: 400px) {
  body {
    background-image: url('img_flowers.jpg');
  }
}

content.text: The HTML <picture> Element
The HTML <picture> element gives web developers more flexibility in specifying image resources.
content.html: The HTML <picture> element gives web developers more flexibility in specifying image resources.

content.text: The most common use of the <picture> element will be for images used in responsive designs. Instead of having one image that is scaled up or down based on the viewport width, multiple images can be designed to more nicely fill the browser viewport.
content.html: The most common use of the <picture> element will be for images used in responsive designs. Instead of having one image that is scaled up or down based on the viewport width, multiple images can be designed to more nicely fill the browser viewport.

content.text: The <picture> element works similar to the <video> and <audio> elements. You set up different sources, and the first source that fits the preferences is the one being used:
content.html: The <picture> element works similar to the <video> and <audio> elements. You set up different sources, and the first source that fits the preferences is the one being used:

content.code_html:
<picture>
  <source srcset="img_smallflower.jpg" media="(max-width: 400px)">
  <source srcset="img_flowers.jpg">
  <img src="img_flowers.jpg" alt="Flowers">
</picture>

content.text: The srcset attribute is required, and defines the source of the image.
content.html: The srcset attribute is required, and defines the source of the image.

content.text: The media attribute is optional, and accepts the media queries you find in CSS @media rule .
content.html: The media attribute is optional, and accepts the media queries you find in CSS @media rule.

content.text: You should also define an element for browsers that do not support the element.
content.html: You should also define an <img> element for browsers that do not support the <picture> element.
